result.markdown:
# Events

So as stated, shifted from providing a network, to providing raw event data.
Opinions?

Example:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
nodes <- data.frame(
  id   = c("1", "2", "3"),
  time = c(0, 1, 2)
)
edges <- data.frame(
  i    = c("1", "1"),
  j    = c("2", "3"),
  time = c(1, 2)
)

ev <- make_events(nodes = nodes, edges = edges)
```
:::


::: {.columns style = "padding-bottom: 2rem;"}

::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event times

| event_id|  t|
|--------:|--:|
|        1|  0|
|        2|  1|
|        3|  2|


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Node arrivals

| event_id|id |
|--------:|:--|
|        1|1  |
|        2|2  |
|        3|3  |


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Edge arrivals

| event_id|i  |j  |
|--------:|:--|:--|
|        2|1  |2  |
|        3|1  |3  |


:::
:::

:::
:::

In the case you only have `edges`, the `make_events()` function will implicitly
generate the nodes as they appear in `edges`. Note this is assuming that nodes
join the network at the first time in which they appear in `edges`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
edges_example <- data.frame(
  i    = c("1", "1"),
  j    = c("2", "3"),
  time = c(1, 2)
)

events_from_edges <- make_events(edges = edges_example)
```
:::


::: {.columns style = "padding-bottom: 2rem;"}

::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event times

| event_id|  t|
|--------:|--:|
|        1|  1|
|        2|  2|


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Node arrivals

|     | event_id|id |
|:----|--------:|:--|
|NA   |        1|1  |
|NA.1 |        1|2  |
|NA.2 |        2|3  |


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Edge arrivals

| event_id|i  |j  |
|--------:|:--|:--|
|        1|1  |2  |
|        2|1  |3  |


:::
:::

:::
:::

There are also two useful helpers for working with events, `edges_by_event()` and
`nodes_by_event()`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
edges_per_event <- edges_by_event(ev)
nodes_per_event <- nodes_by_event(ev)
```
:::


::: {.columns style = "padding-bottom: 2rem;"}

::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 1 Edges

|i  |j  |
|:--|:--|


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 2 Edges

|i  |j  |
|:--|:--|
|1  |2  |


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 2 Edges

|i  |j  |
|:--|:--|
|1  |3  |


:::
:::

:::
:::

::: {.columns style = "padding-bottom: 2rem;"}

::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 1 Nodes

|id |
|:--|
|1  |


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="padding-right: 0.5rem; width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 2 Nodes

|id |
|:--|
|2  |


:::
:::

:::
::: {.column style="width: 232px"}

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}


Table: Event 2 Nodes

|id |
|:--|
|3  |


:::
:::

:::
:::
